The stable Fe3O4 and χ-Fe5C2 phase derived from the equilibrium between oxidation and carburization during CO2-FTS reaction facilitated efficient CO2 hydrogenation into CO via RWGS reaction and subsequent CO-FTS reaction to produce hydrocarbon products. Even so, the product selectivity was still slowly changed during the long-term test. It was considered that the gradually increased carbon accumulation on catalyst surface was a major reason for the shifting product selectivity. Seen from the Raman spectra results of spent catalysts in Figure S38, the much larger D band compared to G band in spent 1.5Na-Fe1Zn1-1000 h catalyst suggested that these deposited carbon species consisted of a large amount of defective carbon sites. These defective sites favored the storage of H* species and thus higher surface H* species concentration on catalyst surface, which resulted in the increasing selectivity to CH4 and alkanes content in C5+ product. In our previous work for CO-FTS reaction over carbon nanotube supported cobalt catalysts, the promotional effect of defective carbon sites on catalytic activity and CH4 selectivity was also observed, which was well demonstrated due to enhanced hydrogen spillover [77]. The decline in C5+ selectivity and shifting to lower carbon number might be also ascribed to the increased carbon deposition, which was accumulated on active iron carbide phase surface to suppress the chain growth. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, this study has taken comprehensive and systematic insights into the effects of Na2S and H2O on the selective and stable production of α-olefins from CO2/H2 and CO/H2 over iron-based catalysts. The key viewpoints have been reached as shown below: (1) The addition of Na2S into 1.5Na-Fe1Zn1 catalyst significantly lowered catalyst activity along with light alkanes and CO as major products in CO2-FTS reaction. It was attributed to the suppression of carburization and oxidation of iron phases with Na2S addition, leading to lower χ-Fe5C2 content, high metallic Fe content with strong hydrogenation ability, and no Fe3O4 for RWGS reaction. However, in CO-FTS reaction, Na2S didn’t show obvious impact on the iron phases evolution but significantly improved catalyst stability by suppressing carbon deposition, which was favorable for the selective and stable production of high-value long-chain α-olefins from CO hydrogenation as shown in Scheme 2 . (2) Combined with catalytic tests and theoretical calculations, the effects of H2O on CO2-FTS reaction have been clarified as suppressing the adsorption and dissociation of H2/CO, subsequent hydrogenation to form CHx*, and their carbon–carbon coupling. Thus, it led to gradual catalyst deactivation in atmospheric-pressure CO2-FTS reaction, along with continuous and linear increase in CO and CH4 selectivity and decrease in lower olefins selectivity. Through hydrophobic modification with SiO2@C16, the favorable desorption of H2O from catalyst surface resulted in more stable CO2 conversion and product selectivity. However, it should be especially pointed out that, in high-pressure CO2-FTS reaction, the hydrophobic structure of SiO2@C16 was seriously destroyed owing to the facile hydrolysis of Si-O-Si-C16 with high H2O steam concentration. Therefore, it is highly expected to develop more stable hydrophobic material with exceptional hydrothermal stability to minimize the negative effects of H2O in high-pressure CO2-FTS reaction for viable commercial application. (3) The optimal 1.5Na-Fe1Zn1 catalyst exhibited excellent stability for reaction activity, along with a slight change of product selectivity during 1000 h long-term CO2-FTS reaction. The stable iron phase stemmed from the equilibrium between carburization and oxidation contributed to the excellent stability for CO2 conversion. The increasing carbon deposition for the storage of H* species was the major reason for increasing CH4 selectivity and alkanes content in C5+ and decreasing C5+ selectivity, owing to enhancing H* species supply and decreasing C–C coupling. Moreover, in order to further increase lower olefins content, the collected liquid-phase CO2-FTS products were cracked in a separate fixed-bed reactor over ZSM-5 nanosheet in the absence of H2. The cracking products were dominantly shifting toward C2-C5 lower olefins with minor C6-C8 aromatics formation as shown in Scheme 2. Ideally, the designed cracking process almost did not result in the formation of undesired CH4 and other light alkanes. coredata.dc:description: Conversion of CO2/H2 and CO/H2 into α-olefins via Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) reaction has stimulated great interest. Herein, iron-based catalysts were developed to produce α-olefins with a tailor-made manner. As-synthesized 1.5Na-Fe1Zn1 exhibited high activity for CO2 conversion, high selectivity toward C2-C5 light olefins along with stable 1000 h run. Separate catalytic cracking of C5+ products over ZSM-5 nanosheet promoted light olefins selectivity up to 64.6 %, benefiting from the elimination of hydrogenation reaction. Interestingly, Na2S showed different effects in CO2-FTS and CO-FTS over iron-based catalysts. In detail, Na2S significantly suppressed catalytic activity and increased selectivity toward alkanes/CO in CO2-FTS reaction. However, it can surprisingly improve catalyst stability in CO-FTS reaction, leading to high activity at about 96 % CO conversion and high selectivity to long-chain C4+ olefins at about 65.4 %. In addition, it was demonstrated that H2O accumulation hindered H2/CO adsorption and dissociation, subsequent hydrogenation into CHx, and their carbon–carbon coupling, which resulted in catalyst deactivation and selectivity shifting toward CH4 and CO in atmospheric pressure CO2-FTS reaction.

coredata.dc:title: Selective production of light α-olefins and long-chain α-olefins from CO2/H2 and CO/H2 over iron-based catalysts: Effects of Na2S and H2O
